awd_titl_txt: Evaluation of the Chemical Drivers behind Membrane Integrity Loss in Halide-Impaired Waters during Chemical Disinfection to Advance Optimal Membrane Structural Design
awd_abstract_narration:
160588
Shah

In recent years, the role of membrane filtration to treat salt-impaired waters has become more commonplace as freshwater shortages have increased the demand for seawater desalination and water reuse. The process of disinfection and desalination of impaired waters is challenged by the extreme variation in water composition. This project presents a fundamental research framework which will enable future informed design of water treatment strategies under such impaired water conditions, specifically with respect to prolonging membrane lifetime. The central aim of this research project is to integrate governing chemical principles of polymers and aqueous phase chemistry to advance the scientific foundation in membrane engineering applications. The project has the following planned outcomes: (1) prediction of membrane degradation following disinfectant exposure in halide-impaired waters, and, (2) informed design of novel membrane surfaces that are resistant to these effects. 

To achieve these outcomes, solid membrane materials and model compounds that serve as their chemical analogs will be used to assess chemical kinetics, by-product formation, and morphological and chemical alterations of the membrane surface. Model feedstock waters will contain various mixtures of halide salts (e.g. chloride, bromide, and iodide ions) as well as chemical disinfectants (e.g. free chlorine and chloramines) in order to measure combined chemical effects. The experimental program will identify the effects of water quality (i.e. salinity, temperature) and operational conditions (oxidant dose). This is especially important given that concentration polarization effects observed during membrane filtration can potentially magnify the impact of such parameters. Finally, this project will inform the design of novel membrane surfaces that minimize membrane failure through chemical and structural modifications. The development of such membrane materials would represent a clear technological advancement which could result in significant energy and economic savings to facilities treating impaired waters. Overall, this project will provide desalination industries and water reclamation utilities valuable insight on how impaired waters with high salt (halide) content will effect membrane performance when various disinfection strategies are applied prior to nanofiltration and reverse osmosis treatment.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Polyamide-based reverse osmosis membranes are applied for desalinating waters such as seawater and brackish groundwater. In fact, they are the industry standard because of their high selectivity and ability to withstand a wide range of pHs. However, one of their pitfalls is their propensity to undergo biofouling, which essentially leads to biological growth on the membrane surface. Biofouling is known to dramatically decrease membrane performance and increase energy consumption. In order to overcome biofouling, a disinfectant, typically free chlorine, is applied; however, free chlorine is known to react with the polyamide layer and result in further membrane deterioration and performance loss.  This issue is also likely exacerbated when waters also contain halides (e.g. bromide and chloride) which can alter chlorine chemistry and potentially enhance membrane degradation.

            Therefore, this work aimed to further explore how and why polyamide membranes are so susceptible towards degradation by free chlorine and other chlorine-based disinfectants such as chloramines. We particularly wanted to explore how the water quality and water matrix that was treated by membrane filtration also played a role.  This issue was especially critical given that desalinated waters in particularly contained high halide concentrations.  It was also evident that while previous studies had explored some of its chemistry with free chlorine, questions and discrepancies still existed.  In addition, many of the studies evaluated the bulk membrane surface when treated with high levels of chlorine disinfectant, and it was often difficult to ascertain the specific reaction pathways leading to membrane degradation within specific sites of the membrane monomers. Thus, this project presented a fundamental research framework which assessed how monomers up to membrane thin films were affected by various chlorine-based disinfectants (e.g. free chlorine or chloramines) under varying water quality regimes. Two water quality parameters that were specifically tested include halide type and concentration and pH.  To tackle this issue, this project integrated governing chemical principles of polymer and aqueous phase chemistry together. This strategy is a significant scientific advance, which led to several key findings: (1) building a robust set of data that included the kinetic reaction rate constants, types of by-products formed, and the reaction mechanisms of the polyamide-based monomers under varying halide and pH conditions, (2) using this information to build a kinetic model to predict membrane degradation as a function of disinfectant exposure, (3) identifying how these reaction mechanisms resulted in changes to membrane performance (e.g. water flux), (4) characterization of chemical and mechanical failure modes for polymer thin films related to membrane technology, and (5) discovery of new methods to rapidly assess the long-term stability of membrane materials.  

Intellectual Merit: It is expected that these major outcomes will subsequently inform future research efforts in how to chemically and/or structurally modify polyamide membrane surfaces so that they can be more resist to chlorine-based disinfectants. This effect will subsequently curb the influence of biofouling, which is will have significant impacts on the long term viability of these membranes and their performance capabilities. This factor is important given the global challenges in providing clean drinking waters to water stricken regions and to do so in an energy efficient and sustainable manner. Overall, it is believed that this research team was well-equipped to successfully accomplish these project objectives based on the PIs? combined expertise in disinfection chemistry and polymer chemistry and synthesis coupled with the unique experimental capabilities of their research groups to link molecular interactions with macroscale membrane performance.

Broader Impacts: Several important broader impacts were also achieved. First, both graduate students (5 total) and undergraduate students (2 total) were provided research training, mentorship, and opportunities to disseminate their research in regional and national settings. Overall, they advanced their research abilities in the areas of membrane filtration, water treatment, disinfection chemistry, and polymer chemistry. The research results and outcomes of this project were also disseminated to other students through one undergraduate/graduate class (CE 497) related to water treatment and also one outreach activity for 130 rising female 7-9thgrade students for the Engineering FYI: For Your Imagination Program at Purdue in July 2018. In addition, the research outcomes were further intended to contribute to the foundational engineering knowledge for the design, processing, and development of polymeric-based membranes with improved chemical resistance and specifically superior performance in treating halide-impaired waters, which will enable efficient re-use and reclamation of water used in industrial and energy production applications. This proposed project will also provide desalination industries and water reclamation utilities valuable insight on how impaired waters with high salt (halide) content will effect membrane performance when various disinfection strategies are applied prior to nanofiltration (NF) and reverse osmosis (RO) treatment.  It will also better assist them in making further decisions about treatment design by considering alternative disinfection options or through selection of NF and RO membranes that have been manufactured differently.
